post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
State representatives and other people in Washington would vie for control of the military and federal agencies previously under the control of the executive branch. Sectors would either split up, be removed, or be actively fought over.

Once the dust settles, you might get a situation where "we all just sorta agree to be cool", but getting there would be an unpredictable rollercoaster.
body_html:
State representatives and other people in Washington would vie for control of the military and federal agencies previously under the control of the executive branch. Sectors would either split up, be removed, or be actively fought over.

Once the dust settles, you might get a situation where "we all just sorta agree to be cool", but getting there would be an unpredictable rollercoaster.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
Every argument against anarchism is a description of *any* status quo.

IE, any sort of natural balance of power.

Anarchism can never be more than a temporary state. Theoretically you can remove all existing power bases, but any human system is going to recalibrate and find homeostasis again somewhere.

Would that homeostasis point be different? Quite possibly. Would it still be anarchy? No. Would it be even more repressive than the previous homeostasis point? Probably.

Smart freedom lovers know you have to try to design a homeostasis point that protects the little guy, and that you do that by giving the little guy leverage over the bigger guy through legal protections of freedom of speech and commerce which all the little guys have a collective incentive to defend and uphold while they're still little, and also constitutionally or otherwise limiting the power of the government to write laws on things which the big guy will inevitably try to coopt and use to bully the little guy. 

Dumb freedom lovers don't know that. They [larp as punk rock anarchists](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ry5URU-Py2Q) and do nothing of consequence.
body_html:
Every argument against anarchism is a description of any status quo.

IE, any sort of natural balance of power.

Anarchism can never be more than a temporary state. Theoretically you can remove all existing power bases, but any human system is going to recalibrate and find homeostasis again somewhere.

Would that homeostasis point be different? Quite possibly. Would it still be anarchy? No. Would it be even more repressive than the previous homeostasis point? Probably.

Smart freedom lovers know you have to try to design a homeostasis point that protects the little guy, and that you do that by giving the little guy leverage over the bigger guy through legal protections of freedom of speech and commerce which all the little guys have a collective incentive to defend and uphold while they're still little, and also constitutionally or otherwise limiting the power of the government to write laws on things which the big guy will inevitably try to coopt and use to bully the little guy.

Dumb freedom lovers don't know that. They larp as punk rock anarchists and do nothing of consequence.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
As a third party to your American struggles... You're really not that well off.

So long as everything goes well, an American is fine. But if one thing goes wrong, say, you develop a chronic illness, or you get into a car wreck you can't sue anyone over (if you even had the money to sue to begin with), you're grade A fucked. 

As a European, I scratch my head every time this topic comes up and some of you defend the status of your nation as 'pretty good'. It sure isn't what it seems like to us. 

Of course, all this is assuming you're not among the minority of the US populace that can actually afford to get sick, injured or in a legal battle without struggling financially for the rest of your life. Would you be willing to explain things to me, assuming I'm missing something terribly obvious?

-Edit- This completely ignores your extremely flawed electional and bureaucratic systems, but one topic at a time.
body_html:

As a European, I scratch my head every time this topic comes up and some of you defend the status of your nation as 'pretty good'. It sure isn't what it seems like to us.

Of course, all this is assuming you're not among the minority of the US populace that can actually afford to get sick, injured or in a legal battle without struggling financially for the rest of your life. post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
What you're saying is by and large untrue. You are seeing the media blast the worst case scenarios. Most people have support networks, there is more safety net than you think, and there are legal protections for debts. Just because the government doesn't always wipe your ass doesn't mean there is no help or hope. The country was set up to be a place where the government doesnt have that power over you. Its not a bad thing. 

The bureaucracy is kind of the same. The gridlock is a marvelous feature that keeps things from changing too fast on a whim and keeps power in check. Same with the electoral college and the whole election process. 

Don't forget, you are being inundated with news stories that are hostile to capitalism and American power. It is in their best interest to make things seem as bad as possible. Things are pretty geeat here if you turn off the news. I wouldn't trade with anyone.

Edit: car insurance covers accidents and medical care. It is rare that people actually sue each other over that.
body_html:
What you're saying is by and large untrue. You are seeing the media blast the worst case scenarios. Most people have support networks, there is more safety net than you think, and there are legal protections for debts. Just because the government doesn't always wipe your ass doesn't mean there is no help or hope. The country was set up to be a place where the government doesnt have that power over you. Its not a bad thing.

The bureaucracy is kind of the same. The gridlock is a marvelous feature that keeps things from changing too fast on a whim and keeps power in check. Same with the electoral college and the whole election process.

Don't forget, you are being inundated with news stories that are hostile to capitalism and American power. It is in their best interest to make things seem as bad as possible. Things are pretty geeat here if you turn off the news. I wouldn't trade with anyone.

Edit: car insurance covers accidents and medical care. It is rare that people actually sue each other over that.

parent.body:
As a third party to your American struggles... You're really not that well off.

So long as everything goes well, an American is fine. But if one thing goes wrong, say, you develop a chronic illness, or you get into a car wreck you can't sue anyone over (if you even had the money to sue to begin with), you're grade A fucked. 

As a European, I scratch my head every time this topic comes up and some of you defend the status of your nation as 'pretty good'. It sure isn't what it seems like to us. 

Of course, all this is assuming you're not among the minority of the US populace that can actually afford to get sick, injured or in a legal battle without struggling financially for the rest of your life. Would you be willing to explain things to me, assuming I'm missing something terribly obvious?

-Edit- This completely ignores your extremely flawed electional and bureaucratic systems, but one topic at a time.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body: I dunno, man. Last I checked Insulin cost 7 euros where I live (and is fully covered) as opposed to the...400ish dollars overseas? I really don't see the appeal.
body_html: I dunno, man. Last I checked Insulin cost 7 euros where I live (and is fully covered) as opposed to the...400ish dollars overseas? I really don't see the appeal.

body:
Look man, the day you can walk up to your prime minister or whatever with a pistol on your hip and call him a fucking faggot is the day I'll give a shit what you Europeans have to say about our governance. As societies, we value different things. I'll take a difficult time paying my bills over a debate in a human trafficking investigation about whether the king can be prosecuted.

Since you're going to ask, https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Dutroux

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
I mean, he comes to work on a bike rather than an armored vehicle and fifteen bodyguards, but I indeed can't carry a firearm. Not that I care to. 

I'll leave the transgressions of government officials out of the discussion. It's common knowledge those are rotten anywhere you go, not just in the US or Belgium.

I agree.

The way we do that is hit the reset button and strip things back down to bare essentials.

How do you think that's going to happen? Vote harder?

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body: Simply put, the problem with the medical industry in our country is that it's over-regulated, which is the reason it's so expensive. Deregulate all the insane restrictions we have on healthcare, and you'll notice the price drop significantly.
body_html: Simply put, the problem with the medical industry in our country is that it's over-regulated, which is the reason it's so expensive. Deregulate all the insane restrictions we have on healthcare, and you'll notice the price drop significantly.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
European Healthcare is regulated to the nines to keep the prices down. That's another thing I keep breaking my head over when looking at the American Healthcare system. It's clearly the *lack* of regulation that causes the prices to be so high, so why do people keep advocating for deregulating it even further? 

Is it astroturfing, or misguided, or are people just brainwashed to believe 'government bad' while corporations wring their hands and giggle at you behind your backs? 

The prices are so high because Healthcare services get to essentially charge whatever they want. Here, prices have a predetermined range for each procedure, and every motion to abolish this is actively struck down by the populace because none uf us want what you guys have got going on, overseas.
body_html:
European Healthcare is regulated to the nines to keep the prices down. That's another thing I keep breaking my head over when looking at the American Healthcare system. It's clearly the lack of regulation that causes the prices to be so high, so why do people keep advocating for deregulating it even further?

Is it astroturfing, or misguided, or are people just brainwashed to believe 'government bad' while corporations wring their hands and giggle at you behind your backs?

The prices are so high because Healthcare services get to essentially charge whatever they want. Here, prices have a predetermined range for each procedure, and every motion to abolish this is actively struck down by the populace because none uf us want what you guys have got going on, overseas.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
This entire video only shows America fucked up a system the Netherlands got right decades ago. It's clear your bills were shit, but social Healthcare has performed exceptionally well across the ocean and anyone who isn't outright homeless can afford the yearly expenditure it requires.

I don't have the time to look into these bills that apparently caused your problems, though. 

And uh... 'theft by every definition' is just false.
body_html:
This entire video only shows America fucked up a system the Netherlands got right decades ago. It's clear your bills were shit, but social Healthcare has performed exceptionally well across the ocean and anyone who isn't outright homeless can afford the yearly expenditure it requires.

I don't have the time to look into these bills that apparently caused your problems, though.

And uh... 'theft by every definition' is just false.

parent.body:
Wrong. Very wrong. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfLdzCt5Zc0

Here, watch this slightly under 4 minute video. It'll explain this better than I can.

EDIT: Also, we don't want universal healthcare because it's evil. It's theft by every definition.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
Taxation is theft. "Universal Healthcare" is funded by tax.

It's immoral to take my money against my will, regardless of why. I'm barely on board with regular tax. Why would I be on board with an anti-capitalistic practice that sentences children to die?
body_html:
Taxation is theft. "Universal Healthcare" is funded by tax.

It's immoral to take my money against my will, regardless of why. I'm barely on board with regular tax. Why would I be on board with an anti-capitalistic practice that sentences children to die?

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
Misappropriated taxes being theft I completely agree with. The government should be there to make life better for you, not worse. If they succeed in doing that, paying tax is essentially paying for a service, even if the pay is mandated.

I urge you to look up statistics on child death rates in Western Europe before you assume anything about a system that has been proven to work just fine when implemented correctly.
body_html:
Misappropriated taxes being theft I completely agree with. The government should be there to make life better for you, not worse. If they succeed in doing that, paying tax is essentially paying for a service, even if the pay is mandated.

I urge you to look up statistics on child death rates in Western Europe before you assume anything about a system that has been proven to work just fine when implemented correctly.

post.title: What if we didn't have a president and we all just sorta agreed to be cool?

body:
Charlie Gard and Alfie Evans. Those are the only things I can imagine when someone talks about Universal Healthcare. 

Misused taxes is such a huge problem in the US that free market capitalism is a better alternative. In a healthy economy, price of goods and services will *never* increase will never increase without a proportional increase of quality (outside of external influences like shortages, something the US generally doesn't have to worry about). The government creates artificial shortages of healthcare by limiting how many doctors we can have as well as mandating that doctors need to provide all these unnecessary services.
body_html:
Charlie Gard and Alfie Evans. Those are the only things I can imagine when someone talks about Universal Healthcare.

Misused taxes is such a huge problem in the US that free market capitalism is a better alternative. In a healthy economy, price of goods and services will never increase will never increase without a proportional increase of quality (outside of external influences like shortages, something the US generally doesn't have to worry about). The government creates artificial shortages of healthcare by limiting how many doctors we can have as well as mandating that doctors need to provide all these unnecessary services.
